title: Merger talks raise fears for Vauxhall's Ellesmere Port plant
text:
The proposed mega-merger between the French owner of Peugeot and Vauxhall, and Italian rival Fiat Chrysler has fuelled fresh fears about the future of Ellesmere Port's plant.

PSA Group yesterday confirmed discussions are being held over a tie-up to create a car manufacturing giant worth almost £40 billion.

The combined firm would be the fourth biggest in the world, behind Volkswagen, Toyota and the Renault-Nissan alliance.

Worry: The Unite union described the talks as 'deeply unsettling' for Vauxhall's UK workers

Between them, PSA Group and Fiat Chrysler – which also owns Jeep and Maserati – sold almost 9m cars last year. Joining forces could allow resources to be spent on developing new technology such as electric cars, while cutting costs.

PSA Group, which is 12 per cent-owned by the French government and bought Vauxhall in 2017, said the merger would create one of the 'world's principal automotive groups'.

But the Unite union described the talks as 'deeply unsettling' for Vauxhall's UK workers, including 1,100 at its Ellesmere Port plant in Cheshire, which has long faced closure.

PSA Group's chief executive Carlos Tavares warned in June that it was prepared to pull the plug on the plant – which makes the Vauxhall Astra – if Brexit renders it unprofitable.

Unite said it would be seeking an 'urgent, high-level meeting' with PSA. Unite national officer Des Quinn said: 'Merger talks combined with Brexit uncertainty are deeply unsettling for Vauxhall's UK workforce, which is one of the most efficient in Europe. If PSA wants to use a great British brand like Vauxhall to sell cars and vans in the UK, then it has to make them here in the UK.'

Analysts have warned job cuts are likely. The talks come after a proposed £29 billion merger between Fiat Chrysler and French car maker Renault collapsed in June. Manufacturers have been looking at teaming up with rivals to enable them to cope better with the huge challenges facing the industry.
